In preparing any country program or strategy, financing any project, or by making any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other 
status of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  developing member countries (DMCs) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in the 
Central and West Asia region comprise Afghanistan, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Georgia, Kazakhstan, 
the Kyrgyz Republic, Pakistan, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, and Uzbekistan. These countries are a 
heterogeneous group, with different economic systems and constraints to growth. They also 
have some important common features. First, countries that were part of the former Soviet 
Union  are  still  transition  economies.  Second,  most  are  landlocked,  increasing  their 
transportation costs; nontrade barriers are high. Third, their exports show little diversification. 
The future of the region lies in implementing a program that helps accelerate the pace of their 
structural  transformation.  This  is  the  process  through  which  gross  domestic  product  and 
employment shares shift from sectors of lower productivity into sectors of higher productivity. 
The process must be induced and facilitated through a set of interventions in different areas, 
beginning with reforms to initiate and support change. Reforms are needed to improve the 
efficiency of service provision and to allow the private sector to participate. Second, to facilitate 
their economic transformation, these countries need to invest in the modernization of their 
transport, energy, and urban systems. At the same time, the process of transformation may 
change infrastructure requirements. These three sectors are critical for structural transformation 
and,  consequently,  for  the  development  of  the  region.  Investment  in  general,  and  in 
infrastructure in particular, has always been considered the key engine of development. For this 
reason,  ADB  assistance  in  energy,  transport,  and  urban  services  are  crucial  for  the 
development aspirations of the Central and West Asia region, as they represent investments in 
infrastructure that will create the necessary capacity to facilitate country development.  
 
2.  The regional departments of ADB are preparing road maps that will improve the quality 
of the policy dialogue with their corresponding member countries. These road maps will help the 
DMCs to better plan their investment needs in the medium and long term. The Central and West 
Asia Department (CWRD) is contributing to this process by preparing road maps for the energy, 
transport, and urban services sectors of its client countries. This technical assistance (TA) will 
provide resources to  develop a template and a generic methodology  for road maps for the 
three sectors. For reasons of priority, the TA will finance country road maps for the three sectors 
for two countries: Kazakhstan and Uzbekistan. CWRD will also prepare regional road maps by 
sector for the whole Central and West Asia region. This will contribute to the development of the 
Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation program. The preparation of road maps for other 
Central and West Asia countries will follow at a later stage using similar methodologies, subject 
to additional financing. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  The experience of today’s developed countries shows that to succeed development 
requires the involvement of the public sector through the provision of basic infrastructure and 
public  services.  Available  empirical  evidence  shows  that  public  investment  in  these  areas 
encourages private investment. Developed country experience also indicates that investment 
activities need to be planned and coordinated with the private sector to avoid mismatches, 
bottlenecks, and waste of scarce resources. Radically changing cities, energy and transport 
systems will require political will, leadership, good management and the active participation of 
the private sector. This is because these changes will probably require reforms, which are 
always  surrounded  by  problems  of  accountability.  This  requires  public  and  private  sectors 
viewed as strategic collaborators.

2  
4.  Optimal planning and coordination of investments are particularly relevant for the Central 
and  West  Asia  region,  where  often  all  three  areas  of  infrastructure  need  replacement  or 
upgrading, or they simply need to be provided. Also, careful planning of investment is important 
as it plays a dual role in the economy, both as expenditure (demand side) and as the source of 
capacity  (supply  side,  i.e.,  addition  to  capital  accumulation).  This  dual  nature  creates  a 
mismatch, as the two effects have different time horizons: while the impact of demand is 
exhausted rather quickly, that of capacity lasts longer. 
 
5.  Investment has microeconomic and macroeconomic consequences for the economy. In 
the first case, it contributes significantly to the improvement of people’s quality of life (e.g., 
through the provision of public goods such as basic urban services). In the second case, an 
increase in investment may cause inflationary pressures and imbalances in the economy. A 
balanced development plan requires coherent planning, both of the forthcoming volume of 
investment and of its composition, which must be directed purposefully toward the breaking of 
supply bottlenecks, for example, in energy.  
 
6.  The role of urban areas must be redefined to facilitate the transformation of traditional 
rural-based economies into modern agroprocessing centers, and to facilitate the development of 
clusters of production and services. This requires a well-articulated urban and regional spatial 
structure. Often, however, urbanization is not essentially due to economic transformation, but is 
the result of migration, with the consequence that urban areas grow haphazardly. For this 
reason, planners must understand how urbanization might evolve in the Central and West Asia 
countries,  explore  the  many  problems  facing  fast-growing  cities  (e.g.,  affordable  housing, 
untreated sewage, mass transit, water shortage, solid waste), and discuss what policy makers 
can do to mitigate the strains of urban life and maximize the opportunities offered by cities. 
Cities in the People’s Republic of China, South Africa, and the United Kingdom were turned 
around in as little as 10 years. ADB’s Strategy 2020 indicates that “to contribute to public health, 
ADB  will  invest  in  water,  sanitation,  and  waste  management  systems.”1 Urban  areas  are 
assumed to drive economic growth and employment for rural and regional development. Indeed, 
cities play a crucial role in national economic growth. This has been the case in Asia, where 
urbanization rates increased very quickly during the last 30 years. Often, urbanization was 
associated  with  the  development  of  manufacturing.  More  recently,  it  is  also  linked  to  the 
development of booming service sectors. However, today many cities struggle with the impact 
of  fast  growth.  Overcrowding,  environmental  degradation,  high  land  costs,  and  worsening 
mobility  of  people  and  goods  impact  negatively  on  industrial  and  business  activities  and 
productivity in general. Therefore, a strategic dialogue with some of the leading global players in 
water supply and sanitation, solid waste management, and urban transport is absolutely critical 
to foster innovative thinking, to enhance private sector participation, and to provide a solid 
response to the enormous transformation challenge that Central Asia faces. 
 
7.  Although Central and West Asia is the only Asian region that is not import-dependent on 
energy, the complex issues that encompass security (i.e., ensuring that an area has adequate, 
affordable, and sustainable sources of energy) are vital for ensuring its economic growth. For 
this, governments need to know where, how, and what kind of power plants and pipelines to 
build. Rapid growth—economic, demographic, urban, and industrial—is pushing the demand for 
energy, and many of the energy linkages that predated the dissolution of the former Soviet 
Union no longer exist. This creates certain regional challenges. 
 
                                                 
1  ADB. 2008. Strategy 2020: The Long-Term Strategic Framework of the Asian Development Bank, 2008–2020. 
Manila ( p. 18).

3 
 
8.  Having modern transport and logistics systems that allow the efficient movement of 
goods and people is fundamental to support structural transformation in a modern economy. A 
modern and efficient transportation system is also important because it is complementary to the 
development of some economic sectors, e.g., tourism. To achieve this, Strategy 2020 indicates 
that ADB will invest in infrastructure to improve transport and communication connectivity within 
and between DMCs.  
9.  Infrastructure  investment  cannot  be  limited  to  building  physical  assets;  governance, 
planning, proactive sector policies in job creation, public transportation, affordable housing, 
shape of urban expansion, and climate change mitigation are all part of the development puzzle. 
Along these lines, ADB will emphasize the delivery of infrastructure services that will create an 
enabling  environment  for  public–private  partnerships  and  private  sector  engagement.  In 
particular, ADB will endeavor to (i) build DMCs’ capacity for better infrastructure management, 
(ii) promote institutional and policy reforms that enhance operating efficiency and sustainability 
of infrastructure projects, and (iii) support logistical systems to increase trade and investment by 
building on basic infrastructure strengths. 
 
10.  ADB will use the road maps as planning tools to help program the different activities at 
the department level so as to maximize the impact of the Bank’s financing. Specifically, road 
maps will assist the departments to redefine their strategic direction by acting as a tool for 
strategic planning. They will also help in discussions with governments and clients in general, as 
a policy tool. Finally, they will assist the relevant divisions plan their portfolio and new pipeline of 
activities, as a tool to guide operations. 
  
11.  Well-defined road maps will help accelerate the modernization of the countries’ transport, 
energy, and urban services sectors, as well as increase their efficiency. This way, ADB intends 
to provide innovative solutions to problems in the three sectors.2 Country and regional road 
maps will be strategic documents that determine the current state of affairs and recommend 
paths forward aimed at meeting a set of objectives. Key strategic objectives are sustainable 
country  and  regional  growth  and  development,  poverty  reduction,  and  higher  economic 
integration. Road maps help meet these objectives by identifying investments, policy changes, 
and other strategies that have the greatest potential for country and regional economic growth.  
 
12.  The road maps developed with the TA will provide a link with the countries’ development 
plans, in particular with the objectives to invest in infrastructure to create capacity, and to 
diversify exports. Diversification ranks high in the agenda of most countries in the Central and 
West Asia region. Development entails shifting resources from the less productive activities of 
the economy, typically agriculture, into industry and services. In this process, countries upgrade 
and  diversify  their  production  and  export  structures,  become  more  urbanized,  and  people 
migrate from rural to urban areas.  
 
13.  Road maps will play a key role in systematizing sector analyses and strategies that 
inform country partnership strategies, country operations business plans, project and program 
reports, and related results frameworks. Their preparation is an integral part of the sector and 
thematic work needed for country and project planning. They will facilitate better alignment with 
DMC plans and priorities and with ADB’s Strategy 2020. They will also provide the basis for 
sector  division  and  resident  mission  dialogue  with  DMC  clients.  Road  maps  will  combine 
analytical, strategic, and planning features. They will be updated as needed to reflect key sector 
developments. They will also provide an analytical link to the “drivers of change” identified in

Strategy  2020:  private  sector  development,  good  governance,  knowledge  solutions,  and 
partnerships.  
 
14.  The urban services road maps will be a tool that will contribute to generating a forward-
looking picture of what cities in the Central and West Asia region will look like. The DMCs in 
Central and West Asia will be able to plan what services these cities will require, how to provide 
them (at an affordable cost) and the necessary financial resources. The development of modern 
cities will be essential for the economic future of these countries. Five areas in particular appear 
to be relevant: (i) water supply and sanitation, (ii) solid waste management, (iii) urban transport, 
(iv) markets and logistics, and(v) municipal finance solutions that strengthen and reinforce 
decentralization  in  the  provision  of  services.  Financial  sustainability  and  private  sector 
participation will be the two key themes in the urban services road maps. ADB’s capacity in 
urban  infrastructure  development  should  catalyze  long-term,  public–private  partnerships  in 
service delivery, alongside strengthened governance and institutions for improved city and 
municipal management. Furthermore, private sector participation in ADB-led urban development 
projects offers the best hope for large and sustained improvements in efficiency, effectiveness, 
and service quality of utility companies and, above all, promotes deep institutional reforms in the 
urban sector.  
 
15.  The energy sector road maps will guide planning for investments in energy. To plan 
investments in energy, sound forecasts of demand and supply of different energy sources are 
required as well as scenarios based on, for example, the likely evolution of prices. Addressing 
the role of renewable sources of energy in the context of growing awareness of climate change 
issues is also important and, given this propose, an optimal energy mix. Three key areas to be 
addressed by the energy road maps will be efficiency, security, and regional trade.  
 
16.  Transportation road maps will suggest paths for system improvements. They will assess 
all  aspects  of  the  existing  transportation  systems,  identify  areas  with  significant  gaps  or 
opportunities for improvement, and target investments and other policies that build upon the 
existing system strengths. To encourage the development of transportation road maps, the 
criterion  by  which  transportation  markets  will  be  judged  to  be  efficient  will  be  competitive 
economic efficiency. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
17.  The impact of the TA will be a series of mutually agreed-upon well-informed country 
strategies  based  on  analytically  sound  sector  road  maps,  as  well  as  the  formulation  and 
implementation  of  country  partnership  strategies,  regional  cooperation  strategies,  and 
development plans by participating governments and ADB. The outcome of the TA will be a 
framework and vision for modern and competitive transport, energy, and urban infrastructure 
and services in Central and West Asia. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
18.  Work under the TA will combine analytical, strategic, and policy dialogue, and support 
the governments’ development agendas. To this purpose, sector road maps will (i) have sound 
analytical foundations, (ii) be based on quantitative analysis, (iii) provide a regional dimension, 
and (iv) be integrated with each other so that they provide a unified view.

5 
 
19.  TA  activities  will  include  (i)  collecting  and  collating  all  necessary  sector  data  and 
information to undertake supply and demand analyses, (ii) analyzing government sector master 
plans, (iii) developing simulations to build likely future scenarios, and (iv) providing financing 
plans for each sector and identifying areas of future ADB involvement. The TA will utilize a 
collaborative  approach  and  rely  extensively  on  consultations  with  government  and 
nongovernment  stakeholders  to  gather  information  and  perspectives,  as  well  as  to  build 
consensus on the future directions for each sector. Discussions and dissemination workshops 
will be organized. These workshops will provide a venue to discuss methodology and outputs, 
as well as to seek synergies with client governments. The final road maps will be presented at 
the ministers meeting for the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation in 2012. Work will be 
led by experts in each sector. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
20.  The  estimated  total  cost  of  the  TA  is  $1,800,000  equivalent.  ADB  will  provide  the 
equivalent  of  $1,500,000  The  TA  will  be  financed  on  a  grant  basis  by  ADB’s  Technical 
Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-other  sources).  The  governments  of  Kazakhstan  and 
Uzbekistan will provide a total of $300,000 equivalent to support TA implementation in their 
respective countries, through the provision of in-kind support in the form of logistical support, 
data provision, and office accommodation. The TA cost estimates and financing plan are in 
Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
21.  ADB will be the executing agency for the TA with the Country Coordination and Regional 
Cooperation Division of CWRD (acting in close collaboration with CWRD sector divisions) being 
the focal point. In collaboration with the sector divisions, the Country Coordination and Regional 
Cooperation  Division  will  prepare  the  sector  terms  of  reference  and  coordinate  consultant 
recruitment  and  technical  aspects  of  the  TA.  International  and  national  consultants  with 
expertise in each of the three sectors (energy, urban services, and transport) and in project 
coordination will implement the TA activities. Consultant selection will be through a firm using 
quality- and cost-based selection with an 80/20 weighting using a full technical proposal in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on The Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to 
time). The TA will require 36 person-months of international consulting and 78 person-months of 
national  consulting.  The  project  coordinator  (24  person-months)  will  be  engaged  on  an 
individual basis. Outline terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3. TA funds will 
be disbursed in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, 
as amended from time to time). The TA will be implemented from January 2011 to December 
2012. The TA team will oversee the outputs of the TA activities, including comments on draft 
papers and coordination of missions to meet governments. The no-objection of participating 
CWRD countries will be confirmed in writing prior to the commencement or financing of TA 
activities in those countries. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,500,000 on a grant basis 
for Preparation of Sector Road Maps in Central and West Asia, and hereby reports this action to 
the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The road maps will have seven sections tailored for each sector and country.  
 
2.  Overview of issues. Provide general background by analyzing strengths, weakness, 
opportunities,  and  threats  of  each  country  and  sector.  In  particular,  assess  the  country’s 
infrastructure demand needs today (and domestic supply capacity in the case of energy). 
 
3.  Forecast of infrastructure demand needs. Identify changes proposed with respect to 
the actual plan, i.e., where are the country and/or sector today and predict where they will be in 
5, 10, 20, 30, or 50 years. 
 
4.  Analysis of country master plan and development strategy for the sector. Include 
analysis of 
 
(i)  government plans and cooperation with relevant agencies;  
(ii)  sector legal frameworks; 
(iii)  sector-specific policies, e.g., job creation, public transportation, energy mix and 
renewable energies, choice between roads and railroads; 
(iv)  support from development agencies; and 
(v)  the impact of regional issues and potential cross-border opportunities. 
 
5.  Analysis of the potential role of the private sector.  
 
6.  Financing plan. Provide 
 
(i)  a funding or investment plan that reflects the costs of the changes proposed,  
(ii)  analysis of the sources of the funds (domestic versus external),  
(iii)  analysis of public sector management and processes in place to implement the 
investment plan as efficiently as possible, 
(iv)  analysis  of  public  sector  financing  and  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB) 
contributions, 
(v)  analysis of the potential contribution of the private sector, and 
(vi)  estimation of the sector and regional benefits that the changes will bring about.  
 
7.  Simulations and scenarios. Identify the options for countries. Assess the pros and 
cons. Prepare simulations and scenarios for the next decades for each sector. 
 
8.  Identification of areas and opportunities for ADB involvement. Include prioritization 
of investments in the next decades. 
 
A.  Energy Specialist (international 12 person-months, and national 18 person-months) 
9.  An international energy specialist will lead the team to conduct country, regional, and 
sector assessments. The specialist will possess a university degree in a field that confers 
significant knowledge of the energy sector, along with at least 15 years experience in the sector. 
National consultants with necessary qualifications and experience to conduct sector surveys for 
energy will be recruited. The energy consultant will undertake the following:  
 
(i)  Collect all available relevant data, information, and reports from government 
agencies, ADB, other development partners, and the private sector on the energy

Appendix 3  11 
sector. Supply-side information will include fossil fuel generation, cogeneration in 
industry,  renewable  energy  generation,  energy  from  waste,  centralized  heat 
generation,  and  transport  fuels  and  biofuels.  Demand-side  information  will 
include demand-side generation and energy efficiency.  
(ii)  Review and analyze available sector master plans and strategies. 
(iii)  Analyze the current energy mix for each country and the region from the point of 
view  of  efficiency,  costs,  and  sustainability.  Project  future  energy  mix  under 
alternative scenarios and simulations. 
(iv)  Undertake country and regional energy demand forecasts for the short, medium, 
and long term. 
(v)  Analyze country and regional sector governance and institutions from the point of 
view of vision, clarity of objectives, operating and regulatory effectiveness, and 
financial  sustainability.  Recommend  institutional  improvements  needed  to 
successfully manage and oversee future transformations in the sector. 
(vi)  Analyze the role of the private sector in the energy sector now and in the future. 
Focus on the likely future role of the public sector. Identify requirements and 
recommend actions to foster successful public–private partnerships in the sector 
for delivery of better services. 
(vii)  Analyze pricing and cost-recovery issues in the sector and recommend actions 
and improvements to enhance financial sustainability. 
(viii)  Identify country and regional investment requirements in the energy sector for the 
short, medium, and long term. 
(ix)  Prepare a comprehensive financing plan for the sector in view of the identified 
investments and chart likely contributions of the public and private sectors in 
meeting the costs of these investments. 
(x)  Identify specific sector investments and institutional improvements for ADB to 
finance and support in the short, medium, and long term. 
(xi)  Specifically  analyze  issues  and  identify  investments  related  to  clean  energy 
investments.  
(xii)  Discuss the future of energy trade and its implications for energy security in the 
region. 
(xiii)  Consider  how  energy  sector  investment  planning  is  linked  to  planning  for 
transport and urban sectors for integrated country and regional infrastructure 
planning.  
(xiv)  Undertake detailed consultations with all stakeholders and organize discussion 
workshops.    
(xv)  Include all of the above to develop cohesive and comprehensive country and 
regional energy sector road maps.  
(xvi)  Organize  dissemination  workshops  to  discuss  completed  road  maps  with 
stakeholders.    
 
B.  Transport Specialist (international 12 person-months, and national 18 person-months) 
10.  An international transport specialist will lead the team to conduct country, regional, and 
sector assessments. The specialist will possess a university degree in a field that confers 
significant knowledge of the transport sector, along with at least 15 years experience in the 
sector. National consultants with necessary qualifications and experience to conduct sector 
surveys for transport will be recruited. The transport consultant will undertake the following:

12  Appendix 3 
 
(i)  Collect all available relevant data, information, and reports from government 
agencies,  ADB,  other  development  partners,  and  the  private  sector  on  the 
transport sector. This includes information on all modes of transport and logistics.  
(ii)  Review and analyze available sector master plans and strategies. 
(iii)  Assess the current country and regional situation of the transport sector from the 
point of view of efficiency, costs, and sustainability. Develop future scenarios of 
transport modes and utilization. 
(iv)  Undertake country and regional transport demand forecasts and projections for 
the short, medium, and long term. Assess transport sector needs from the point 
of view of expanding trade integration in the region. 
(v)  Analyze country and regional sector governance and institutions from the point of 
view of vision, clarity of objectives, operating and regulatory effectiveness, and 
financial  sustainability.  Recommend  institutional  improvements  needed  to 
successfully manage and oversee future transformations in the sector. 
(vi)  Analyze the role of the private sector in the transport sector now and in the 
future. Focus on the likely future role of the public sector. Identify requirements 
and recommend actions to foster successful public–private partnerships in the 
sector for delivery of better services. 
(vii)  Analyze pricing and cost-recovery issues in the sector and recommend actions 
and improvements to enhance financial sustainability. 
(viii)  Identify country and regional investment requirements in the transport sector for 
the short, medium, and long term. 
(ix)  Prepare a comprehensive financing plan for the sector in view of the identified 
investments and chart likely contributions of the public and private sectors in 
meeting the costs of these investments. 
(x)  Identify specific sector investments and institutional improvements for ADB to 
finance and support in the short, medium, and long term. 
(xi)  Consider how transport sector investment planning is linked to planning for the 
energy  and  urban  sectors  for  integrated  country  and  regional  infrastructure 
planning.  
(xii)  Undertake detailed consultations with all stakeholders and organize discussion 
workshops.  
(xiii)  Include all of the above to develop cohesive and comprehensive country and 
regional transport sector road maps. 
(xiv)  Organize  dissemination  workshops  to  discuss  completed  road  maps  with 
stakeholders.    
 
C.  Urban Specialist (international 12 person-months, and national 18 person-months) 
11.  An international urban specialist will lead the team to conduct country, regional, and 
sector assessments. The international specialist will possess a university degree in a field that 
confers significant knowledge of the urban sector, along with at least 15 years experience in the 
sector. National consultants with necessary qualifications and experience to conduct sector 
surveys for the urban sector will be recruited. The urban sector consultant will undertake the 
following:  
 
(i)  Collect all available relevant data, information, and reports from government 
agencies, ADB, other development partners, and the private sector on the urban 
sector. This will include specific information on water supply and sanitation, solid 
waste management, urban transport, and housing subsectors with a focus on the

Appendix 3  13 
state of infrastructure and public finances available to support and augment this 
infrastructure.  
(ii)  Review and analyze available sector master plans and strategies. 
(iii)  Assess  the  current  country  and  regional  situation  of  the  identified  urban 
subsectors from the point of view of efficiency, costs, and sustainability. Develop 
future scenarios for each subsector. 
(iv)  Undertake country and regional demand forecasts and projections for the short, 
medium, and long term for each subsector.  
(v)  Analyze local, municipal, country, and regional sector and subsector governance 
and institutions from the point of view of vision, clarity of objectives, operating 
effectiveness, and financial sustainability. Consider experiences with centralized 
versus decentralized models of delivery of urban services, urban planning and 
policy  formulation,  and  regulation.  Recommend  institutional  improvements 
needed  to  successfully  manage  and  oversee  future  transformations  in  the 
various subsectors. 
(vi)  Analyze the role of the private sector in the urban subsectors now and in the 
future. Focus on the likely future role of the public sector. Identify requirements 
and recommend actions to foster successful public–private partnerships in the 
subsectors for delivery of better services. 
(vii)  Analyze pricing and cost-recovery issues in the subsectors, and recommend 
actions and improvements to enhance financial sustainability. 
(viii)  Identify investment requirements in the country and regional urban subsectors for 
the  short,  medium,  and  long  term  from  the  point  of  view  of  enhancing 
international  economic  competitiveness  of  cities  and  towns  in  the  selected 
countries. 
(ix)  Prepare a comprehensive financing plan for the urban sector and subsectors in 
view of the identified investments, and chart likely contributions of the public and 
private sectors in meeting the costs of these investments. 
(x)  Identify specific sector and subsector investments and institutional improvements 
for ADB to finance and support in the short, medium, and long term. 
(xi)  Consider how urban sector investment planning is linked to planning for the 
transport and energy sectors for integrated country and regional infrastructure 
planning.   
(xii)  Undertake detailed consultations with all stakeholders and organize discussion 
workshops.    
(xiii)  Include all of the above to develop cohesive and comprehensive country and 
regional urban sector road maps.  
(xiv)  Organize  dissemination  workshops  to  discuss  completed  road  maps  with 
stakeholders.       
 
D.  Project Coordinator (national 24 person-months) 
12.  The project coordinator will provide technical and coordinating support in the preparation 
and implementation of the sector road maps. The consultant will work under direct supervision 
of Central and West Asia Regional Department staff. The consultant will also help manage, 
administer,  and  monitor  the  project.  The  responsibilities  of  the  consultant  will  include  the 
following:  
 
(i)  Provide technical inputs in the preparation of the sector road maps, including 
macroeconomic  analysis  and  analysis  of  the  energy,  transport,  and  urban 
services sectors.

14  Appendix 3 
 
(ii)  Analyze and draft reports on the structural transformation of client countries as 
inputs to the analysis of strengths, weakness, opportunities, and threats for each 
client country. 
(iii)  Assist in building simulation models for analysis. 
(iv)  Monitor activities related to the program, and coordinate and correspond with 
international experts and partner institutions.  
(v)  Help implement the sector road maps. 
(vi)  Build a database for project monitoring and implementation.  
(vii)  Participate in consultation and monitoring missions, as required. 
(viii)  Undertake other tasks as required to complete the project.
